The factors, I think, are probably a little different in each case, but the bottom line that became very, very clear to me as I went through this agonizing process was that there had to be two really iron-clad rules.
One is: Are we absolutely certain of guilt?
No error or possibility for error whatsoever.
And let me just say on that one, increasingly across the country I think the public's faith--I know my faith--has been shaken, that what may seem iron-clad is, in fact, iron-clad.
You know, there were 14 people in recent years released from death row based on clear DNA evidence that said they didn't do it.

Also, by the way, if 14 were released based on that evidence, it seems pretty certain to me that there were innocent people executed prior to this before we had the knowledge of DNA the way we do today.

But in addition to that, the facts of the case, we've got to be absolutely certain that there's no bias in the system whatsoever, no racial bias, no procedural bias or anything of this type, you know.

As you're probably aware, just yesterday Maryland did execute another individual, and while my great sympathy goes out for the family, because this was a horrendous crime, and I also know that it's difficult for any governor, including the incumbent governor, go through this, I am not at all sure that this case didn't run head-on into the second issue of being no bias.
After numerous charges of racial and geographic bias in our system, I commissioned a study back in I think it was 2000.
And that study, among other things, found that the majority of the death sentences in Maryland were when a black male killed a white person in Baltimore County.

Understand, Baltimore County is not a high crime area, and understand also most of the homicides are actually black on black, and yet if you fall into this pattern where a black killed a white in Baltimore County, chances are you're gonna be executed.
Well, this gentleman who was just killed fell exactly into that pattern.

Now that doesn't mean that he didn't commit the crime, and it doesn't mean that there's any less just terrible, terrible sympathy for the victim and her family and her grandchildren who were there at the time of the killing...
Yes.
